text: one of the first terms we always talk
about when we're working in 3d
technologies for creating movies and
entertainment is this idea of how we see
that the distance between our eyes is an
extremely important thing we call that
the inter ocular distance the reason
that's important is a few factors but
primarily the distance between our eyes
and for most of us grown human beings
it's roughly two and a half inches the
reason that's important is because it
helps dictate the scale of everything we
see in the world so things that look big
to us and things look small to us or
based on the fact that we have two eyes
two and a half inches apart they also of
course give us the illusion of depth
because we're seeing two different views
of objects that create this illusion of
depth perception and of course our brain
is doing a lot of work now in the sense
of working in 3d movies we have this
situation where we have to basically
simulate reality it's really an illusion
of 3d because a very technical level
what we're doing is creating a fairly
convincing illusion of three dimensions
from one vantage point this isn't like a
hologram where we can move around it
it's really a single vantage point we
take advantage of the fact that movie
theaters people don't walk around so
they don't see the artifice of the
illusion so much but essentially we have
to use two cameras that would simulate
how we see now you might think it's as
easy as taking two cameras and putting
them two and a half inches apart but
unfortunately our eyes don't work like
cameras certainly our lenses don't work
like lenses and our retinas don't work
like camera sensors so we have to do an
approximation and we call the distance
between the cameras this interaxial
distance because it's a variable now
technically speaking we rarely use
cameras that are side by side like this
because when we create the illusion of
3d we're actually dealing with an
interaxial separation that's much
narrower than our own inner ocular
distance of two and half inches so
oftentimes we're dealing with something
down about an inch so we have these very
complicated camera rigs that will allow
us to do that but suffice it to say the
inter axial distance is one of the two
very important things about creating the
illusion of 3d when we take two cameras
and we photograph something the space
between them will dictate how deep the
shot looks from the closest to the
farthest object so if we want more depth
in a shot we'll we'll move the cameras
apart farther if we want less depth will
pull them together so that's part of the
illusion but at a certain point if the
cameras are too far apart if you
consider the inter ocular distance of an
animal like a mouse
the very tiny inter ocular objects that
look small to us might look very large
to them because of their scale and
because the distance between our eyes in
fact a lot of animals their eyes are so
close together to get accurate depth
cues if you ever watch birds for example
in a tree and their heads are moving

as a depth cube to understand better how

the small animal like a mouse or a large

inter ocular we had this issue of scale
we have to deal with if we have two

example if this is a condition called
hyper stereo we end up miniaturizing the

some sporting events recently been shot
in 3d they tend to put cameras way up at
the top of the stadium and they'll pull
them really far apart to give you some

the Lilliputians just took up football
it doesn't look like they're far away it
looks like they're tiny people which
might be useful you know Gulliver's
travel 3d or something but you know it's
a it's a strange phenomenon and this
happens a lot of you ever used view
masters as a kid I was always fascinated
with Mount Rushmore I grew up in the

carve a mountain in two phases this is
amazing so grandparents gave me the view
master of Mount Rushmore and going
through the photographs I realized it
looked very tiny to me I thought what's

out they photographic with two cameras
that are really far apart to give the

miniaturised it so it wasn't a very

a look at those images in 3d they're on
a monitor or on a screen we have a
problem with those images in that
infinity is rectify it's rendered at the
wrong distance from us the viewer it
actually shows up right at the screen
surface which means infinity is far too

quite uncomfortable to look at so we
have to use this technique called

that depth that we've dialed in with the

into the screen to some reasonable
distance we do that in a variety of ways

essentially if you look at these lenses
on a camera system at a certain point in
space those points will cross and that
point we call it the convergence point
so if we're photographing an actor we
put the convergence point on the actors
face they will appear right at the
screen plane it's
right the surface of the screen and
anything in front of them will be in
front and anything behind will be behind
the reason that's important becomes much
clearer in post-production because there

you may have witnessed some of these on

these can be somewhat hard to look at on
